tweets.author: Trezor

tweets.content:
IMPORTANT: Trezor firmware and hardware wallets are not affected by the Nx/NPM supply-chain attack. The attack involved malicious JavaScript packages from the public npm registry. This technology is not being used in Trezor firmware at all.

As always, remember:
âœ… Hardware wallets keep your keys secureâ€”even if software is compromised
âœ… Always verify the address on your Trezor screen

Stay safeğŸ”’

tweets.content:
ğŸ‘‰ Adding phishing alerts to Trezor Suite and trezor.io

Stay safe.

We want to reassure you that there has been no recent breach of the email database. The phishing attempts weâ€™ve seen are widespread across the crypto industry.

tweets.author: Trezor

tweets.content:
What we are doing.

Weâ€™re fighting back these scams by:

ğŸ‘‰ Partnering with @PhishFort to take down phishing sites (~48.79 hours per takedown)
ğŸ‘‰ Reporting scam domains and fake listings
ğŸ‘‰ Submitting phishing ads for removal

tweets.author: Trezor

tweets.content:
Trezor Suite downloads.

Youâ€™ll rarely need to download Trezor Suiteâ€”usually just once during setup or for a new computer. Always download from trezor.io, nowhere else.

ğŸ‘‰ trezor.io/trezor-suite

tweets.author: Trezor

tweets.content:
âš ï¸ We will never ask for your wallet backup. Be cautious, even if domains look legit.

8/12
tweets.author: Trezor

tweets.content:
How to spot a scam.

Always verify senders and links:

âœ… Official Trezor emails: noreply@trezor.io
âœ… Official site: trezor.io/

Scammers often use similar-sounding domain names, but it's easier to filter if you verify the address. 

7/12
tweets.author: Trezor

tweets.content:
Feeling pressured? Pause.

Scammers use fear and urgency to trick you. If you get a message demanding fast action:

ğŸ“ Hang up calls
ğŸ’¬ Ignore DMs
ğŸ“§ Close email tabs

Take a breath. Verify on your terms. If your wallet backup is offline and secure, your crypto is safe.

6/12
tweets.author: Trezor

tweets.content:
Red flags.

Scammers may ask for:

ğŸš©â€œRecovery key,â€ â€œbackup code,â€ or â€œpassphraseâ€
ğŸš©Passwords or 2FA codes
ğŸš©Personal info disguised as a â€œbug fixâ€ or â€œsecurity checkâ€

If anyone asks for these, itâ€™s a scam. Never share sensitive info.

5/12
tweets.author: Trezor

tweets.content:
âš ï¸ NEVER share your wallet backup, aka recovery seed (12/20/24 words). 

Itâ€™s only entered on your Trezor device during wallet recovery, which is rare.

4/12
tweets.author: Trezor

tweets.content:
ğŸ‘‰ Phishing ads and fake apps/websites
ğŸ‘‰ Bogus social media profiles impersonating our team

The common trick.

Phishing emails often come from legitimate email platforms using trusted-sounding domains. They look real but arenâ€™t.

3/12
tweets.author: Trezor

tweets.content:
Whatâ€™s happening?

Scammers are impersonating exchanges, Trezor Support, other wallet brands, and even our team. 

Theyâ€™re using:

ğŸ‘‰ Fake emails (â€œAI Wallet Update,â€ â€œSecurity Incidentâ€)
ğŸ‘‰ Scam calls pretending to be support
ğŸ‘‰ Counterfeit Trezor devices on retail sites

Important

Over the past few weeks, we've noted an increase in phishing attempts targeting users to steal their wallet backup (aka recovery seed). Please stay alert.

Our advice remains the same. Always:

âœ…Verify website URLs and sender email addresses

âœ… Avoid clicking on suspicious links

âœ… Never enter your wallet backup online â€“ under any circumstances

We will NEVER ask for your wallet backup in any form of communication. Any message that does is a scam.

Your vigilance is your strongest defense. Stay safe.
